noun.description: The power or quality of giving delight or arousing admiration.
examples: his charm has captivated the media

noun.description: A small ornament worn on a necklace or bracelet.
An object, act, or saying believed to have magic power.
examples: the dreamcatcher is a charm used to prevent bad dreams

noun.description: One of six flavors of quark.

examples: the books have charmed children the world over

verb.description: Control or achieve by or as if by magic.
examples: she will charm your warts away

phrases: before I could turn on the charm, they hung up
He relaxes, and he comes alive - he turns on the charm.
After a slickly co-ordinated annual meeting which saw Rose and his equally debonair chairman Paul Myners turn on the charm, Green realised that he was on to a loser.
Yet, for all his protestations and refusal to talk to James, actions speak louder than words, and yesterday the Englishman had turned over a new leaf and turned on the charm.
But this isn't a man who turns on the charm at the hint of a camera flash or the whirr of a journalist's Dictaphone.
origin: Middle English (in the senses incantation or magic spell and to use spells): from Old French charme (noun), charmer (verb), from Latin carmen song, verse, incantation.
